questions.text: In which condition is the Codman's triangle seen?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Codman's triangle is most commonly seen in osteosarcoma due to aggressive periosteal elevation caused by rapid tumour growth.

  • Codman's triangle is a triangular area of subperiosteal new bone formation.
  • It appears when the periosteum is lifted off the bone by a rapidly growing tumour, and the body reacts by depositing new bone beneath it.
  • It is a classic, though not pathognomonic, sign of osteosarcoma, a highly malignant bone-forming tumour.
  • While Codman's triangle can be seen in other aggressive lesions, it is most frequently associated with osteosarcoma.

Explanation of other options:

Ewing's sarcoma (Option A): More commonly associated with onion-skin (lamellated) periosteal reaction.

Osteoblastoma (Option C): Benign tumour, typically shows minimal periosteal reaction.

Metastasis (Option D): Often causes lytic lesions but rarely stimulates periosteal reactions like Codman's triangle.

Key Takeaway:

Codman's triangle is a periosteal reaction typically associated with rapidly growing tumours like osteosarcoma.

questions.text: Which of the following is also called Codman's tumour?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Codman's tumour is the eponym for chondroblastoma, a rare benign cartilage-forming tumour arising from the epiphysis of long bones in adolescents.

  • Chondroblastoma is a benign but locally aggressive tumour, most commonly found in the epiphysis or apophysis of long bones.
  • It typically presents in adolescents and young adults, with pain and swelling in the affected joint.
  • Codman was the first to describe this lesion, hence the term "Codman's tumour."
  • It is radiolucent with sclerotic margins and often requires curettage and bone grafting.

Explanation of other options:

Osteoblastoma (Option A): Benign tumour of posterior spine elements; not known as Codman's tumour.

Osteochondroma (Option B): Common benign bone outgrowth; no eponym relation with Codman.

Osteosarcoma (Option D): Associated with Codman's triangle (a radiological sign), not Codman's tumour.

Key Takeaway:

Chondroblastoma is referred to as Codman's tumour and should not be confused with Codman's triangle seen in osteosarcoma.

questions.text: A 20-year-old male presents with pain in his left hip and thigh and limping for the last 1 year. His X-ray is given below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The presence of a lytic lesion in the proximal femur with marked bowing deformity ("shepherd crook" deformity) is a hallmark radiographic sign of fibrous dysplasia.

  • Fibrous dysplasia is a developmental anomaly where normal bone is replaced by fibrous tissue and immature woven bone.
  • It may be monostotic (single bone) or polyostotic (multiple bones).
  • Common locations: ribs, femur, craniofacial bones.
  • The "shepherd crook" deformity refers to varus bowing of the proximal femur, typically seen in polyostotic fibrous dysplasia.
  • Associated with a ground-glass appearance on X-ray.

Explanation of other options:

Congenital coxa vara (Option B): Presents in early childhood with a reduced neck-shaft angle; no lytic lesion or progressive bowing.

Proximal femoral focal deficiency (Option C): Congenital absence or hypoplasia of the proximal femur; presents in infants or toddlers.

Tom Smith's arthritis (Option D): Refers to septic arthritis of the hip in infants, leading to destruction-not bowing-with joint involvement.

Key Takeaway:

The "shepherd crook" deformity on X-ray is characteristic of fibrous dysplasia, especially when involving the proximal femur in a young adult.

choices.text: Emergency surgery to excise the tumor
Core biopsy to confirm the diagnosis

questions.text: A 20-year-old woman presents with a painless swelling in her left thigh for the last 6 years. It was initially growing slowly, but has been static in size for the last 3 years. She does not have any other symptoms. The X-ray is given below. What is the next line of management?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Asymptomatic osteochondroma in a skeletally mature patient with no recent growth requires no active intervention.

  • Osteochondroma is the most common benign bone tumour, usually arising from the metaphysis of long bones, particularly around the knee.
  • Radiological features:
    • Bony projection with a cartilage cap.
    • Continuity of cortex and medullary canal with the parent bone.
    • Grows away from the nearby joint.
  • Growth stops after skeletal maturity.
  • Management depends on symptoms or suspicion of malignant transformation.
    • Indications for surgery: pain, neurovascular compromise, cosmetic concern, cartilage cap >1.5 cm, or growth after skeletal maturity.

Explanation of other options:

Emergency surgery (Option A): Not indicated unless there is pain, rapid growth, or functional impairment.

MRI (Option B): Useful only if malignancy is suspected or lesion is causing pressure symptoms.

Core biopsy (Option C): Not required when classical features of osteochondroma are seen with no clinical red flags.

Key Takeaway:

In an asymptomatic, static osteochondroma in a skeletally mature individual, no active treatment is required. Observation is sufficient.

questions.text: A 17-year-old boy presents with chronic dull aching pain in the right leg for the last 4 months. The pain is worse at night and shows marked relief with NSAIDs. CT scan reveals a small radiolucent cortical lesion with dense surrounding sclerosis in the diaphysis of the tibia. What is the most appropriate treatment of choice for this lesion?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Radiofrequency ablation is the preferred treatment for small benign bone-forming lesions such as osteoid osteoma.

  • Osteoid osteoma is a benign osteogenic tumour commonly affecting adolescents.
  • Characteristic presentation includes nocturnal pain relieved by NSAIDs.
  • CT imaging identifies the nidus surrounded by reactive sclerosis.
  • Treatment of choice:
    • CT-guided radiofrequency ablation (RFA) is minimally invasive and effective.
    • The probe tip is heated to induce thermal necrosis of the nidus.
    • Eliminating the nidus leads to the resolution of symptoms and sclerosis regression.

Explanation of other options:

Excision of the swelling (Option A): Previously used; now replaced by RFA due to lower morbidity.

Radiotherapy (Option B): Not used due to benign nature and risk of radiation-induced malignancy.

Chemotherapy (Option C): Reserved for malignant bone tumours; not indicated here.

Key Takeaway:

CT-guided radiofrequency ablation is the treatment of choice for osteoid osteoma due to its precision, safety, and high efficacy.

choices.text: Erosion of the cortex of the parent bone
Increase in size of cartilage cap to more than 2 cm

questions.text: Which of the following is considered the most specific radiological indicator of malignant transformation in an osteochondroma?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The most specific feature indicating malignant transformation of an osteochondroma is cartilage cap thickness >2 cm, especially in adults.

  • Osteochondroma is a benign cartilage-capped bony outgrowth from the metaphysis of long bones.
  • Malignant transformation typically occurs into secondary chondrosarcoma.
  • Most reliable clinical and imaging signs of malignancy include:
    • New-onset pain
    • Continued growth after skeletal maturity
    • Loss of corticomedullary continuity
    • Disorganized calcification within cartilage
    • Cartilage cap >2 cm (most specific marker)
  • MRI or ultrasound is preferred to assess cartilage cap thickness.

Explanation of other options:

Erosion of the cortex of the parent bone (Option A): May be seen due to mechanical pressure; not a sign of malignant change.

Codman's triangle (Option C): Classic for aggressive periosteal reaction in osteosarcoma, not seen in osteochondroma.

Onion peel periosteal reaction (Option D): Typically associated with Ewing's sarcoma, not osteochondroma.

Key Takeaway:

A cartilage cap thickness greater than 2 cm is the most reliable radiological feature indicating malignant transformation of osteochondroma.

questions.text: Match the following bone tumours with their associated genetic mutations:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Each of the listed bone tumours is associated with a well-established genetic abnormality:

  • Hereditary Multiple Exostosis (HME): Caused by EXT gene mutations, especially EXT1 and EXT2.
  • Fibrous Dysplasia: Associated with GS alpha gene (GNAS1) mutations.
  • Ewing's Sarcoma: Classic translocation is t(11;22) leading to the EWS-FLI1 fusion gene.
  • Synovial Sarcoma: Defined by t(X;18) translocation, forming SYT-SSX1/SSX2 fusion.

These genetic abnormalities play a role in diagnosis and occasionally in therapy or prognosis.

Key Takeaway:

Bone tumours often show characteristic genetic mutations that aid in diagnosis-e.g., EXT gene mutation in HME and t(11;22) in Ewing's sarcoma.

questions.text: Which of the following benign bone tumours can cause pulmonary metastasis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Though considered benign, a few bone tumours may show unpredictable behaviour and metastasise to the lungs:

  • Giant Cell Tumour (GCT):
    • Despite being histologically benign, pulmonary metastasis can occur in ~3% of cases.
    • This is referred to as benign metastasising GCT.
  • Chondroblastoma:
    • Also carries a small but notable risk (~1%) of lung metastasis, despite being a benign cartilaginous tumour.

Hence, both GCT and Chondroblastoma are benign tumours that can rarely metastasise to the lungs.

Key Takeaway:

GCT and chondroblastoma are benign bone tumours that can rarely metastasise to the lungs-an exception to the general rule that benign tumours don't metastasise.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs can be used in the treatment of GCT of pelvis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Denosumab is a human monoclonal antibody used in the treatment of GCTs located in surgically challenging sites such as the pelvis or sacrum.

  • GCTs are composed of neoplastic stromal cells that express RANKL (Receptor Activator of Nuclear Factor Kappa-B Ligand).
  • Denosumab binds RANKL, inhibiting its interaction with RANK receptors on osteoclasts.
  • This suppresses osteoclast-mediated bone destruction, causing tumour regression.
  • Especially useful in lesions not amenable to complete curettage or resection.

Explanation of other options:

Alendronate (Option A): Bisphosphonate, not primarily used for GCT treatment.

Zoledronic acid (Option B): Bisphosphonate with potential anti-osteoclastic activity but not first-line.

Tocilizumab (Option D): IL-6 receptor blocker, used in inflammatory conditions-not indicated in GCT.

Key Takeaway:

Denosumab is the drug of choice in inoperable or pelvic GCTs due to its targeted anti-RANKL action.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents with gradually increasing pain and swelling around her left knee for 3 months. X-ray reveals an eccentric, expansile, lytic lesion in the epimetaphyseal region of the distal femur with a soap-bubble appearance. What is the treatment of choice?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The clinical, radiological, and histopathological findings are diagnostic of a giant cell tumour of bone, most commonly seen in skeletally mature individuals in the epimetaphyseal region.

  • Extended curettage is the treatment of choice.
  • It involves aggressive curettage followed by the use of adjuvants (e.g., phenol, liquid nitrogen, bone cement) to destroy residual tumour cells and reduce recurrence.

Explanation of other options:

Excision of the swelling (Option A): Done in aggressive or recurrent lesions, or when joint salvage is not feasible.

Radiotherapy (Option B): Reserved for inoperable cases due to the risk of malignant transformation.

Simple curettage (Option D): Inadequate and associated with a higher recurrence rate.

Key Takeaway:

In an epimetaphyseal lytic lesion with characteristic histology in a young adult, extended curettage is the preferred treatment to minimise recurrence and preserve joint function.

questions.text: Which of the following is false regarding hemangioma of the vertebra?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Vertebral hemangioma is a benign vascular tumour of the spine, commonly found incidentally on imaging.

  • Most lesions are asymptomatic and require no treatment.(Option D ruled out)
  • On X-ray, it shows vertical striations known as the Corduroy sign or jail bar appearance. (Option B ruled out)

Corduroy/jail bar sign

  • On CT scan, it shows the polka dot sign due to thickened vertical trabeculae seen in axial cuts. (Option A ruled out)

Polka dot sign

Emergency excision is not indicated unless the lesion is causing neurological deficits due to aggressive growth or compression, which is rare.

Key Takeaway:

Vertebral hemangioma is a benign, typically asymptomatic lesion. Emergency excision is not required unless there are compressive symptoms.

questions.text: 'Chinese letter pattern' on biopsy is seen in which of the following tumors?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Chinese letter pattern on biopsy is a classic histological finding in fibrous dysplasia.

  • Fibrous dysplasia is a developmental anomaly where normal bone is replaced by fibrous tissue and immature woven bone.
  • On histology, irregular trabeculae of immature woven bone are arranged in a branching curvilinear pattern without osteoblastic rimming, resembling Chinese characters - hence the name.
  • This pattern is also referred to as the "alphabet soup" appearance.
  • Most commonly affects the ribs, proximal femur, and craniofacial bones.

Explanation of Other Options:

Giant Cell Tumour (Option A): Shows multinucleated giant cells dispersed among mononuclear stromal cells.

Adamantinoma (Option C): Shows epithelial cells in fibrous stroma with islands of basaloid cells.

Chondroblastoma (Option D): Shows chondroblasts with chicken wire calcification, not Chinese letters.

Key Takeaway:

Fibrous dysplasia characteristically shows a "Chinese letter" pattern on histology due to immature woven bone trabeculae in fibrous stroma.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a part of McCune-Albright syndrome?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Multiple joint contractures are not seen in McCune-Albright syndrome, which classically includes polyostotic fibrous dysplasia, café-au-lait spots, and precocious puberty.

  • McCune-Albright syndrome is a genetic disorder caused by postzygotic activating mutations in the GNAS1 gene affecting Gs alpha protein signalling.
  • It typically presents with:
    • Polyostotic fibrous dysplasia (multiple bones involved)(Option B ruled out)
    • Café-au-lait macules with irregular borders ("coast of Maine" appearance)(Option C ruled out)
    • Precocious puberty (especially in girls)(Option D ruled out)
  • Joint contractures are not a feature and are more typically seen in syndromes like arthrogryposis.

Key Takeaway:

McCune-Albright syndrome includes polyostotic fibrous dysplasia, café-au-lait spots, and precocious puberty, not joint contractures.

questions.text: Which of the following produces 'vertebra plana' in a child?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Eosinophilic granuloma is the most common cause of a vertebra plana (flattened vertebra) in children.

  • Vertebra plana refers to the complete collapse of the vertebral body with normal adjacent disc spaces
  • In children, the most common cause is eosinophilic granuloma, a form of Langerhans cell histiocytosis.
  • It is typically self-limiting and may heal spontaneously.
  • In adults, vertebra plana is more often due to multiple myeloma or metastasis.

Explanation of Other Options:

Simple Bone Cyst (Option A): Typically seen in long bones of growing children; not known to cause vertebral collapse.

Hemangioma (Option B): Common benign vertebral tumour in adults; does not produce vertebra plana.

Multiple Myeloma (Option D): Most common cause of vertebral plana in adults, not children.

Key Takeaway:

Eosinophilic granuloma is the most common cause of vertebral plana in children, often presenting with localised back pain and characteristic imaging findings.

questions.text: A 16-year-old boy presents with painful swelling of his left thigh for the last 1 month. The X-ray is shown below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Osteosarcoma classically presents in adolescents with painful swelling in the metaphyseal region of long bones and a Codman's triangle on imaging.

  • Osteosarcoma is the most common primary malignant bone tumor in children and adolescents.
  • It typically arises in the metaphysis of long bones (distal femur, proximal tibia).
  • Radiological hallmark: mixed lytic-sclerotic lesion, sunburst appearance, and Codman's triangle due to periosteal elevation.
  • Pain and swelling are common presenting symptoms.

Explanation of Other Options:

Ewing's sarcoma (Option B): Diaphyseal location, onion-skin periosteal reaction; less common in metaphysis.

Chondrosarcoma (Option C): Occurs in adults >40 years; often affects axial skeleton, not metaphysis in children.

Adamantinoma (Option D): Occurs in tibial diaphysis in young adults; slow-growing, rare in metaphysis.

Key Takeaway:

A painful metaphyseal lesion with Codman's triangle in an adolescent is diagnostic of osteosarcoma.

questions.text: Which is the most common site of chondrosarcoma?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Chondrosarcoma most commonly arises from the pelvis, followed by the proximal femur. Its axial location helps differentiate it from other bone tumors that more frequently affect the appendicular skeleton.

  • Chondrosarcoma is a malignant cartilage-forming tumor.
  • It primarily affects middle-aged and older adults.
  • The pelvis is the most commonly involved site, followed by the proximal femur.
  • X-ray findings may show endosteal scalloping and punctate calcification.

Explanation of Other Options:

Proximal humerus (Option A): Common site for simple bone cysts, not chondrosarcoma.

Proximal femur (Option B): Secondary common site in chondrosarcoma, but not the most common.

Knee joint (Option D): Common site for GCT and osteosarcoma, not for chondrosarcoma.

Key Takeaway:

Pelvis is the most frequent site of origin for chondrosarcoma, aiding in radiologic and clinical diagnosis.

questions.text: Which of the following is a radiosensitive bone tumour?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Ewing's sarcoma is the most radiosensitive primary bone tumor in humans.

  • Most bone tumors are radioresistant.
  • Exceptions include:
    • Hemangioendothelioma
    • Ewing's sarcoma
    • Lymphoma of bone
    • Plasmacytoma
      (Mnemonic: HELP)
  • Ewing's sarcoma shows dramatic regression with radiotherapy, especially in inoperable cases.

Key Takeaway:

Ewing's sarcoma is a rare exception among bone tumors due to its high radiosensitivity, unlike most others which require surgery or chemotherapy.

questions.text: A 52-year-old man presents with chronic lower back pain and constipation. Imaging reveals a midline sacral mass, and biopsy shows large vacuolated cells with bubbly cytoplasm. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The diagnosis is chordoma, which characteristically shows physaliferous cells on histopathology.

  • Chordoma is a malignant tumor originating from remnants of the notochord.
  • It is the most common primary malignant tumor of the sacrum in adults.
  • Common sites:
    • Sacrum - 50%
    • Clivus - 35%
  • Physaliferous cells are large vacuolated tumor cells with a bubbly appearance, pathognomonic for chordoma.
  • Typical age group: 40-70 years.

Explanation of Other Options:

Adamantinoma (Option A): Occurs in tibial diaphysis, not associated with physaliferous cells.

GCT (Option B): Shows multinucleated giant cells and stromal cells, not bubbly cytoplasm.

Hemangioendothelioma (Option D): Vascular origin tumor; does not exhibit physaliferous cells.

Key Takeaway:

Physaliferous (bubbly) cells are histological hallmarks of chordoma, a notochordal malignancy, especially in the sacrum or clivus.

questions.text: Which of the following tumours produces sclerotic metastasis to bone?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Prostate cancer classically produces osteoblastic (sclerotic) metastases to bone.

  • Bone metastases can be:
    • Osteolytic (e.g., lung, thyroid, renal cell carcinoma, melanoma)(Option B ,C, D ruled out)
    • Osteoblastic (e.g., prostate carcinoma)
    • Mixed (e.g., breast cancer)
  • The sclerotic pattern is due to increased bone formation stimulated by tumor-secreted factors.
  • On imaging, prostate metastases appear as dense, radiopaque lesions.

Key Takeaway:

Prostate carcinoma is the most common tumor to produce sclerotic bone metastases, unlike most other carcinomas that cause lytic lesions.

questions.text: 'Winking owl sign' is seen in which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The "winking owl sign" is a classical X-ray finding seen in spinal metastasis.

  • On an AP view of the spine, the vertebral body with its pedicles appears like an owl's face.
  • Destruction of a single pedicle due to metastatic infiltration leads to the disappearance of one "eye," resembling a winking owl.
  • Most commonly caused by metastatic lesions from breast, lung, or prostate cancers.

Explanation of Other Options:

Multiple myeloma (Option A): Shows diffuse osteolytic lesions but does not characteristically produce the winking owl sign.

Osteomyelitis (Option C): May cause vertebral destruction but not the specific pedicle loss seen in winking owl sign.

Osteoid osteoma (Option D): Typically affects the posterior elements and presents as a nidus with surrounding sclerosis-not related to this sign.

Key Takeaway:

Winking owl sign represents pedicle destruction on spinal X-ray and is classically seen in spinal metastasis.

questions.text: In which condition is 'raindrop skull' seen?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The term "rain drop skull" refers to the presence of multiple small, punched-out lytic lesions in the skull, giving the appearance of rain drops falling on the calvaria.

  • It is one of the hallmark radiological features of multiple myeloma.
  • These lesions result from osteoclastic activity stimulated by plasma cells in the bone marrow.
  • Most commonly observed in older adults presenting with bone pain and anemia.

Explanation of Other Options:

Spinal metastasis (Option B): Involves the vertebrae and may show pedicle destruction (winking owl sign), not skull lytic lesions.

Osteomyelitis (Option C): Typically presents with bone destruction and periosteal reaction but not diffuse skull lesions.

Osteoid osteoma (Option D): Presents with a nidus and surrounding sclerosis, not multiple lytic lesions.

Key Takeaway:

Rain drop skull is a radiological feature seen in multiple myeloma, due to diffuse osteolytic lesions in the skull.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a recognized cause of pain in an osteochondroma?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Pain in osteochondroma can arise due to complications like bursitis, mechanical irritation, fracture, or nerve compression. However:

  • Malignant transformation, though rare, occurs into chondrosarcoma, not osteosarcoma.
  • Hence, development of secondary osteosarcoma is not a cause of pain in osteochondroma.
  • Bursitis is the most common cause of pain in osteochondroma, especially in locations like scapula or proximal femur.(Option A ruled out)
  • Fracture of pedicle or stalk due to trauma can also lead to acute localized pain.(Option B ruled out)
  • Nerve compression from a large exostosis near joints can cause neurogenic pain or paresthesia.(Option C ruled out)
  • Malignant change, when it occurs, typically leads to chondrosarcoma in adults after skeletal maturity.

Key Takeaway:

Pain in osteochondroma is usually due to bursitis, fracture, or nerve compression-not due to secondary osteosarcoma, which is not a recognized transformation in these tumors.
